column1: In this lesson
column2: we'll talk most specifically about what you should expect from CS7637. We'll start by talking about the learning goals
column3: the learning outcomes
column4: and the learning strategies that we'll use for this class. Then we'll discuss the class projects and assessments. That will lead us to talking about something called Computational Psychometrics
column5: which is one of the multi-weighting principles behind the projects in this class. Next we'll talk about the Raven's Progressive Matrices test of intelligence. I think you're going to find it fascinating. The Raven's Progressive Matrices test of intelligence are the most commonly used tests of human intelligence. And that test was the target of the projects in this class. Very ambitious
column6: you're going to enjoy it. FInally we'll discuss something commonly reoccuring principle in this class and you should be on the lookout for them.

column1: There are four major learning goals for this class. First
column2: you'll learn about the core methods of knowledge-based AI. These methods include schemes for structured knowledge representation
column3: methods for memory organization
column4: methods for reasoning
column5: methods for learning
column6: [UNKNOWN] architectures as well as methods for meta reasoning. Meta reasoning is reasoning about reasoning. Second
column7: you learn about some of the common tasks addressed by knowledge-based AI
column14: you will learn ways AI agents can use these methods to address these tasks. Fourth
column15: you learn the relationship between the knowledge-based AI cognitive science. Using theories of human cognition to inspire their design of human level
column16: human-like AI and using AI techniques to generate testable hypothesis about human cognition.

column1: What are the learning outcomes of this course? At the conclusion of this class
column2: you will be able to do three primary things. First
column3: you'll be able to design
column4: implement and evaluate and describe knowledge-based AIs. The design and description of knowledge-based AI agent is really the first learning goal. In order to be able to design an agent
column5: you need knowledge of the methods of knowledge-based AI. Second
column6: you will also be able to use these strategies to address practical problems. This learning outcome addresses the second learning goal
column7: where you will be able to [INAUDIBLE] the relationship between AI agents and real world problems. Third
column8: you'll also be able to use the design of knowledge-based AI agents to reflect on human cognition and vice versa. This addresses the fourth learning goal.

column1: During this course
column2: you'll complete a variety of different kind of assessments. These assessments play different roles. First
column3: they help you learn by demonstrating and testing what you know. Second
column4: they help you reflect on what you've learned. Third
column5: they help us understand what material is being taught well
column6: and what is not being taught well. The main assessment of the projects. You'll complete a series of programming projects in designing AI agents that address a pretty complex task. We'll talk a little bit more about it in a few minutes. Second
column7: written assignments. We'll compete a number of written assignments that will tie the course material to the projects. Third
column8: tests. There will be two tests in this class using the content of this class to introduce a broad variety of problems. Fourth
column9: exercises. Throughout the lessons there'll be a number of exercises to help you evaluate and manage your own learning. Fifth
column10: interactions. We'll be looking at the interactions of the forum and other places to get a feel for how everyone is doing and how can we help improve learning

column1: In this class we'll use five main learning strategies. First
column2: Learning by Example. Almost every lesson of this class starts with an example of the type of reasoning we want you to learn. The example that runs throughout the lesson
column3: could demonstrate that reasoning. Second
column4: Learning by Doing. In most lessons
column5: the lesson will end with a multi-part exercise
column6: where you are doing the exact reasoning that you learned in that lesson. There's first you see an example
column7: then you do a similar example yourself. Third
column8: Project-Based Learning. The class is largely structured around a series of challenging projects. And you will frequently be asked to relate each lesson you learn
column9: to the projects in the class. Personalized learning. Personalization permeates throughout this course. You can watch the lessons in any order you choose
column10: and at your own pace. You can choose which concepts to focus on
column11: and everything the assignments. You'll receive personal feedback on every exercise throughout the course. Fifth
column12: Learning by Reflection. At the conclusion of each lesson
column13: you'll be asked to reflect on what you learned in that particular lesson. At the conclusion of each project
column14: you'll write a designed report that will reflect on the experiments that you did as part of the project. We'll also use other learning strategies as needed

column1: Let us talk about Computational Psychometrics a little bit. Psychometrics itself is a study of human intelligence
column2: of human aptitude
column3: of human knowledge. Computational Psychometrics for our purposes
column4: is the design of computational agents that can take the same kind of tests that humans do
column5: when they are tested for intelligence or knowledge or aptitude. Imagine that you design an AI agent that can take an intelligence test. After designing it
column6: you might want to analyze how well does it do compared to the humans on that test? You might also want to compare the errors it makes with the errors that humans make. If it does as well as humans do and if its behavior
column7: its errors are the same as those of humans
column8: you might conjecture then that perhaps its reasoning mirrors that of humans. In this class
column9: we are going to be designing AI agents that can take the Raven's Test of Intelligence. In the process
column10: we will want to use this agents to reflect on how humans might be addressing the same intelligence tests.

column1: The class projects will be based on the Raven's Progressive Matrices test of intelligence. This test was written in the 1930s to examine general human intelligence. It consists of 60 multiple-choice visual analogy problems. The Raven's test is unique among intelligence test in that all problems in the Raven's test are strictly visual. No words. It is the most widespread
column2: the most commonly used
column3: the most reliable test of intelligence. The Raven's test consists of two kinds of problems
column4: two by two matrix problems and three by three matrix problems. We'll also consider a special case of two by one matrix problems. They're not part of the original test. But they will providing a baseline for starting to construct AI agents. Your project will be to implement AI agents that can solve problems like those that appear in the Raven's Test of Intelligence. Let's look at a few sample problems right now.

column1: The problem with David's answer
column2: in my opinion is that at a certain level humans too are just processing signals and inputs in the right way. What then makes us intelligent? Intelligence is hard to define. In the life sciences
column3: scientists study life
column4: but don't always agree on a definition of life. Similarly
column5: in the cognitive sciences
column6: we study intelligence
column7: but don't necessarily define it. And knowledge based AI
column8: will take the view that knowledge is central to human level intelligence.

column1: Our discussion of knowledge-based agents in this CS7637 class is organized around seven principals. Be on the lookout for the seven principals
column2: they'll occur again and again throughout the course. Principal number one
column3: agents use knowledge to guide reasoning and they represent and organize this knowledge into knowledge structures. Principle number two
column4: learning is often incremental. This connects back to one of the characteristics of problems
column5: where data and experience was coming incrementally. Number three
column6: reasoning is top down not just bottom up. We just don't reason from data
column7: we also use data to pull out knowledge from memory
column8: then we use this knowledge to generate expectations to make sense of the world. Principle number four
column9: knowledge-based AI agents match methods to tasks. We'll discuss a number of different methods. We'll also discuss several tasks. Later
column10: we'll discuss how AI agents can select specific methods to address particular tasks and even integrate different methods to address complex tasks. Principle number five
column11: agents use heuristics to find solutions that are good enough. They do not necessarily find optimal solutions. This is because of a trade off between computer efficiency and the optimality of solutions. Our focus will be on using bounded rationality and yet
column12: giving near real-time time performance on [INAUDIBLE] intractable problems. This happens
column13: because agents use heuristics to find solutions that are just good enough. Principle number six
column14: agents make use of recurring patterns of problems in the world. Of course
column15: there are a number of problems. But even this number of problems are characterized the patterns that occur again and again. Number seven
column17: learning and memory constrain and support each other. We'll build theories that are not just theories of reasoning or theories of learning or theories of memory
column18: but we'll build theories that unify the three of them into one single cognitive system. These principles will come again and again in this particular class. So we highly recommend that you take a moment
column19: pause the video and read over the principles once again.

column1: Throughout this course
column2: we will be using materials drawn from a number of different textbooks and papers. You'll find specific references to all these sources for this examples in the Class Notes. Generally
column3: however
column4: we will use a handful of books from which we will draw a lot of material. Artificial Intelligence by Patrick Winston. Knowledge Systems by Mark Stefik
column5: Artificial Intelligence by Elaine Rich and Kevin Knight and Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach by Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig. You don't have to buy any of these books. But if you want to increase your knowledge beyond what we'll discuss in this class
column6: you may want to consider both these text books and the specific references at the end of each lesson.

column1: Let us look at a connection between your class projects and human cognition. Beginning with psychometrics
column2: psychometrics is the science of measuring human intelligence
column3: aptitude
column4: and knowledge. Computational psychometrics is the science of building agents that can take the same tests of intelligence that humans take. All the [INAUDIBLE] building AI agents that can address the Ravens test of intelligence
column5: it will provide opportunities for thinking about human cognition. While we will be looking only for how well your agents perform on the Ravens test
column6: in principle [INAUDIBLE] psycho-metrics will also look at the kinds of errors that AI agents make. If the errors the AI agents make are similar to those that humans make
column7: then that may provide a source of hypothesis about human thinking on this Raven's Test of Intelligence. It is also interesting to note that people with autism perform about as well on the Raven's Test of Intelligence as neurotypical people. This is a little surprising
column9: people with autism do not perform as well on other tests of intelligence as the neurotypical people. Note that Raven's test of intelligence is the only test that consists only of visual analogy problems. All other tests of intelligence also include a large number of verbal problems. Might I suggest that some of the thinking strategies that people with autism are better aligned with visual reasoning.
